title: Does an author know exactly what they're going to write, or do they come up with stuff while writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s two types of writers… Plotters (or planners), and pantsers. Plotters plan their plot as a timeline, with all its twists and turns, right through to the end before beginning to write the book itself. Others, like myself, write by the seat of their pants (hence ‘pantsers’). I usually have no more than a few ideas in my head, and two or three themes I want to explore, noted down. I then write a scene involving each subject - for example, in one book (http://lrd.to/disrespected) I wanted to include arranged marriage and honour crime, a hijack of a bus, illicit firearms sales, and identity theft/fraud. I wrote a scene involving each, then put them into some kind of order and filled in the gaps to get the ball rolling… cutting the scenes to show things that were happening at the same time but in different locations. As I wrote each separate thread, I let the characters lead me (I write series fiction, so by now I know my core characters well). I believe that if I have to keep turning pages to find out what’s happening next, so will my readers. As the threads develop, I get an idea where it’s going to lead and write an ending. I then begin to steer the plot towards that ending. Once I get to the ending I’ve written, I write a twist in the tail, often a short final chapter, or even just on the last page, to surprise the reader again. This is my usual method of writing my novels. Of course, during the journey, sometimes another idea comes into my head… for example, I decided as a whim, to kill off a good guy character. This led to her partner hunting down the killer in a car chase, confusing the police even more because they still hadn’t connected the different crimes. There’s a FREE e-book available with two complete short prequels to my series. Go to http://lrd.to/this-is-lena and click on the link which will take you to the book’s page on your local Amazon site. Both these short stories were written in the same ‘pantser’ manner. There are also links to the rest of my books.

No one, with the exception of God, and Trump-of course, knows exactly what they are going to write, say or do. Everyone else has an inclination, a variety of feelings and knowings that are forming, I think, that meld enroute, perhaps not as bold as a world tour but rivalling a coast to coast tour with intended/cannot miss stops. Enroute to each stop we are deterred by myriad distractions but kept from most by a copilot / navigator , schedule, itinerary or such. In writing we have our editor and publisher no doubt overseeing and a well thought out overview and mind set. But the assignment is largely, a well fleshed out and focused probability which needs to evolve according to writer’s style, preference, prerogative and circumstance. Just as no writer or traveler proceeds without pit stops, no writer knows exactly what the writing content will be devoid of revisions, alterations, additions and deletions -which are all part of the writing process and novel’s production melding in progress. Adding workable bits and essential ideas as they come to mind is what raises the writing often from good to excellent, and it empowers the author to trust their thoughts and judgment.-for who would or could ignore a good and fitting thought.

Some writers plan out well in advance - and know the whole story in meticulous detail. Others have a general idea of where they are going… Stephen King claims that he doesn’t know what’s going to happen on page 2 whilst he’s writing page 1… Quentin Tarantino says that when Mr Blonde took the razor from his boot in Reservoir Dogs he had no idea what he was going to do with it… Different strokes for different folks… I try to write - I’d love to be spontaneous and just write, but I plan… Often so much planning that I don’t get to do the actual writing.

Lately, I know exactly the plan. Not the specifics. But the specifics arrive. The plan, two days ago: The subject is a younger Elf Magestrix. Her father was of a high bloodline. Her mother was his apprentice. She has silver and red hair. A staff with a blue crystal. Travels the land, righting wrongs according to her own personal code. She is well spoken, educated, diplomatic, but somewhat of a wild card. She rules a border province devastated by chaos magic centuries ago. Though she is an Elf, she feels a kinship more with the Wizards of the Magocracy, rather than the Elves that live in the Mountain passes. Write her story. Yesterday's plan: Detail a guild of local (mostly dwarven) thieves that have stolen the Gauntlet of Anvilfinger from the Warden of the Citadel of the Thane, throwing three families vying for power into chaos, thus destabilizing the frontier defenses in the local area. The guild has "30?” members. Among them are Dwarves whose clan name has been stripped. Others are brigands, road bandits seeking a haven, or pirates hiding out miles from the coastal towns. Write about the Guild, defenses.. what is the hideout like? Write how this all ties in with the Protagonist.

I would say both. He or she might have an outline (i.e. a basic plot or thematic idea) and sketch things out, but a lot of the time it’s common to wing it once you’ve put pen to paper and edit afterward. This may or may not be true for other writers but in my experience, both as a writer, and speaking to other writers, it’s fairly common. E.L. Doctrow had this to say about authoring a novel: It's like driving a car at night. You never see further than your headlights, but you can make the whole trip that way.

I write song lyrics (among other things) and almost never know how a song will end when I start working on it. I generally start with an ideal or a phrase and go from there. I’ve gotten three to four verses in, still not knowing how the damn thing will end. Often, the ending will sound like I started with it and wrote the whole song leading up to it, but actually the ending, when it finally came, surprised even me. Early in his career, Hemingway lost a suitcase full of manuscripts. When asked if he could reproduce the stories, he said, “No, because I know how they end.”

Of course every writer is different, but I have never known exactly what was going to happen in anything I have written. I tend to have a timeline and an outline of events, often just in my head. My characters always surprise me and it does not go well if I try to force them to do what I want them to do. I’ve often said it’s a good thing they don’t know how to type or they wouldn’t need me.

It is both, but the most part - you have to plan them from the beginning. A routeles ship is destined to be lost on the sea. As my experiences, planning the outline is the backbone of every writing. Otherwise, you can get stuck many times trying to connect events to each other. But of course there will be times that your pen will flow on its own. Many authors have changed the details of their characters repeatedly while writing their books.

I don't. I generally make shit up as I go along, which is why I stick to shorter forms of writing. Douglas Adams is supposed to have done things that way, but was inventive enough to get out of any seeming dead ends.
Sometimes you know what you’re going to write, and sometimes you just have a feeling that you’re going to write something .
